review.title: Understanding and Visualizing the District of Columbia Capital Bikeshare System Using Data Analysis for Balancing Purposes
review.abstract: Bike sharing systems' popularity has consistently been rising during the past years. Managing and maintaining these emerging systems are indispensable parts of these systems. Visualizing the current operations can assist in getting a better grasp on the performance of the system. In this paper, a data mining approach is used to identify and visualize some important factors related to bike-share operations and management. To consolidate the data, we cluster stations that have a similar pickup and drop-off profiles during weekdays and weekends. We provide the temporal profile of the center of each cluster which can be used as a simple and practical approach for approximating the number of pickups and drop-offs of the stations. We also define two indices based on stations' shortages and surpluses that reflect the degree of balancing aid a station needs. These indices can help stakeholders improve the quality of the bike-share user experience in at-least two ways. It can act as a complement to balancing optimization efforts, and it can identify stations that need expansion. We mine the District of Columbia's regional bike-share data and discuss the findings of this data set. We examine the bike-share system during different quarters of the year and during both peak and non-peak hours. Findings reflect that on weekdays most of the pickups and drop-offs happen during the morning and evening peaks whereas on weekends pickups and drop-offs are spread out throughout the day. We also show that throughout the day, more than 40% of the stations are relatively self-balanced. Not worrying about these stations during ordinary days can allow the balancing efforts to focus on a fewer stations and therefore potentially improve the efficiency of the balancing optimization models.

sections.text: The popularity of bike-sharing systems has steadily increased in recent years, and the management and maintenance of these emerging systems are indispensable components of these systems. Visualizing current operations can help to better understand the performance of the system. In this paper, a data-mining approach is used to identify and visualize some important factors related to bike-sharing operations and management. To consolidate the data, we bundle stations that have a similar intake and output profile on weekdays and weekends. We provide the time profile of the center of each cluster, which can be used as a simple and practical approach to approximate the number of intake and output points of the stations. In addition, we define two indices based on the shortages and surpluses of the stations that reflect the degree of compensation assistance a station needs. These indices can help improve the quality of bike-sharing experience over at least two days.

sections.heading: LITERATURE REVIEW
sections.text: "The concept of the Bike-Share system was introduced in Amsterdam in 1965 (9) and has evolved through the introduction and development of many bicycle technologies such as smartphones. Since the introduction of the Bike-Share system, much research has been done on various aspects of these systems, some of which are descriptive, mining the data to gain a better understanding of the operations, others are prescriptive and suggest ways to improve the operations, the most commonly used prediction model relates to balancing. Various studies have focused on mathematical optimization and have addressed the problem of realignment by developing mathematical models for the repositioning of bikes in the system (6,10-16).A large part of the descriptive models develops prediction models for the departure and arrival rates, and bicycle availability. sections.heading: Data
sections.text: Capital Bikeshare is a program operated by Motivate International, Inc., and is jointly owned and sponsored by the District of Columbia, Arlington County, the City of Alexandria, VA, and Montgomery County, MD. It offers various membership packages that vary by membership period. The first 30 minutes of each trip are free for members, and additional surpluses will follow for every 30 minutes.Capital Bikeshare was the largest bike share system in North America until May 2013. It is currently the fourth largest in North America. As of July 2016, Capital Bikeshare had 3,050 bikes and 391 stations. In the presence of these many stations, analyzing and visualizing each station for itself is impractical. To better visualize the bikeshare data, the stations should be aggregated, the stations aggregated based on similarity and similarity.

sections.heading: Methodology
sections.text: In this paper, two different visualizations and clusters of the bike share data are offered: one is the hourly pick-up / drop-off trends (profiles) of the stations; the other is based on the imbalance of the individual stations; the stations are grouped according to their general profile patterns to achieve the first goal of showing the pick-up / drop-off trends of the stations; and for the second goal, the stations are categorized by their ADMS and ADME for the day. ADMS and ADME will be defined in more detail later in this methodology section.

sections.heading: Clustering Methodology for Visualizing Daily Temporal Trends of Stations
sections.text: Clustering is based on the temporal (hourly) profile of the percentage of pickups / drop-offs during different hours of the day. We chose the percentage of pickups / drop-offs instead of the number of pickups / drop-offs because different stations have different capacities. This clustering aims to group the stations that have similar trends together and not those of similar size. The clustering methodology has five main steps: 1) data pickups; 2) the aggregation of data; 3) the normalization of pickups and drop-offs of stations; 4) the removal of stations with atypical behaviors; 5) the identification of an appropriate number of clusters in the K-Means. sections.heading: Categorizing the Stations based on Maximum Shortage (ADMS) or Excess (ADME)
sections.text: ADMS measures the maximum scarcity of a station during a given period, averaged over every day of a quarter. ADME measures the maximum excess. To calculate the maximum scarcity of a station between 1 and 2, we sort all pickups and pickups for the station that happen between 1 and 2, based on their occurrence time, so that the earliest pick-up or drop-off occurs first. We start with the shortage at 1. Then we process each pick-up and pick-up individually. Every time we see a pick-up, we increase the shortage, and every time we see a waste, we reduce the shortage. Once the entire list of pickups and drop-offs is processed, we take the maximum positive number that we had for the shortage, as the maximum scarcity for that particular period of the day. The smallest negative number is the maximum overrun, and when we see a waste, we reduce the shortage. sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: As part of an ongoing effort to improve the efficiency of bike share systems, this study uses clustering methods to consolidate data retrieved from Capital Bikeshare, one of the largest bike share systems in North America. Methods used can help visualize overall trends in pickup and drop-off, but they can also help identify compensation requirements required at different times of the day. Stations are grouped at different times of the day based on their imbalance severity, and this approach can be used to identify stations with a high probability of being full or empty, and then deal with these problematic stations by applying various techniques such as applying pickup / drop-off incentives to / from these stations. Results show that most of the pickups and drop-offs occur during morning and afternoon spikes for Capital Bikeshare, whereas pickups and drop-offs are distributed more evenly during the weekends.
